description:
Ascidiimonas aurantiaca is a species of bacteria that belongs to the phylum Bacteroidetes. It is a Gram-negative, aerobic, and non-spore-forming bacterium. Ascidiimonas aurantiaca was first isolated from the surface of a sea squirt (Ascidiacea) collected from the Yellow Sea in China.

The cells of Ascidiimonas aurantiaca are rod-shaped and motile, with a single polar flagellum. The colonies formed by this bacterium on agar plates are typically orange-colored, due to the production of carotenoid pigments. This pigmentation is the basis for the species name "aurantiaca," which means "orange-colored" in Latin.

Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequences has shown that Ascidiimonas aurantiaca is closely related to other marine bacteria within the Bacteroidetes phylum, particularly within the genus Maribacter. However, Ascidiimonas aurantiaca is distinct from other known Maribacter species based on its unique phenotypic and genotypic characteristics.

The ecological role of Ascidiimonas aurantiaca in its natural marine environment is not yet fully understood, but it is believed to be involved in the degradation of complex organic compounds and the cycling of nutrients in the marine ecosystem.
